div.p:
Let us first of all
pray to our God
ye he will vouch
safe to graunt us
an happy, speedie,
and verie fruite
full proceeding in
the declaratio of
the otehr Articles of Christian be
leefe.

the fift Article of our beleefe is:
The third day he rose againe from the
dead. And this Article verily of
our beleefe is in a manner the chiefe
of all the rest. Neither are the A
postles so busily occupied in delcaring
and confirming the other, as they
are in this one. For it had not been
ynough, if our Lord had died onely,
unlesse he had also risen from the dead
againe. For if hee had not risen from
the dead, but had remained still in
death, who shoulde have perswaded
us men, that sinne was purged by
the death of Christ, that death was
vanquished, Sathan overcome, and
Hell broken uppe for the faithfull by
the death of Christ? Yea verily wee
have foolish fellowes that woulde
never cease to blaspheme the verie
God, to make a mocked of our hope,
and to say: Tush, who did ever re
turne from the dead, to tell us whe
ther there be a life in an other worlde
after this or no, and what kind of life
it is?

Because therefore we cannot finde
that anie man did ever returne from
the dead, that is to bee doubted of
which these bablers do tatle touching
the life of the worlde to come.

That the Lorde therefore might de
clare to the whole worlde, taht after
this life there is an other, and that the
soule dieth not with the bodie, but
remaineth alive, hee returned the
third day alive againe to his Disci
ples: and at that instant shewed them,
that sinne was purged, death disar
med, the divell vanquished, and hell
destroyed.

For the sting of death is sinne. Or
the reward of sinne is death. The di
vil hath the power of death, and shut
teth in hell for sinnes. Now therefore,
in that Christ riseth alive againe from
the dead. Death could have no domi
nion over him: and because Death by
suffering the Lord to passe, is broken,
It must needes followe, that the Di
vell, and Hell, are vanquished by
Christ. And lastly, that Sinne, the
strength and power of them all is
purely purged.

It is evident therefore, that the
resurrection of our Lord Jesus Christ
doth as it were, certifie and by seale
assure us of our salvation and Re
demption, so that now wee can not
anie longer doubt of it. Wee con
fesse therefore in this Article, that
our Lorde Jesus Christ is risen a
gaine, and that he is risen againe
for our behoofe, that is to saie, that
he hath wipte away our sinnes, and
that for us he hath conquered death, ye
devill and hell, according to the saying
of the Apostle.

God hath saved us, and hath called us
with an holie calling, not according
to our workes, but according to his
owne purpose and favour which was
given unto us through Jesus Christ be
fore all beginning, but is declared
openly now by the appearing of our
Saviour Jesus Christ who hath verily
put out death, and brought foorth
life, light, and immortalitie by the
Gospell. There are manie more like
this in the 4. of his epistle to the Ro
mans, and in the 15 of his first to the
Corinthians. For the Lord also in the
Gospell after S. John saith, I am the
resurrection and the life: hee that be
leeveth in mee, although he be dead
shall live: and everie one that liveth
and beleeveth in me, shall not die for
ever.

Nowe also let us throughly consi
der everie worde of this article seve
rally by it selfe, Wee confesse ye Lorde,
his resurrection. But a resurrection is
to rise againe. That riseth which fal
leth. The bodie of Christ fell, therefore
the bodie of Christ riseth, yea it riseth
againe, that is to say, the verie same
bodie of Christ, which before it fell did
both live and stirre, doth nowe rise a
gaine, it doth I say both live and stirre
againe. For truely sayde Tertullian
of the resurrection of ye flesh, that this
word Resurrectio is ot properly spo
ken of any thing, save of ye which first
fell. For nothing can rise againe but ye
that fell. For by rising againe, because
itsel, we say the resurrection is made.
Because this sillable Re, is never ad
ded, but when a thing is done againe.
Wherefore the women in the Gos
pell, when they went to annoint the
bodie of the Lorde, which hoong upon
the crosse, did heare the Angell of the
Lorde say, Whie seeke ye the living
among the dead? He is not here, but is
risen, & c.

This historie of the Lordes resur
rectio is set forth in ye 24. after Luke,
and the 16. after Marke. Peter the A
postle, also in the seonc of the acts, af
firming the Lordsresurrection by the
testimonie of David, doeth expresly
shewe, that the Lord is verilie risen a
gaine.

After this we say againe, that hee
is risen out of, or from ye dead. Which
member doth expresse the trueth, both
of his death and resurrection For the
bodie or flesh dieth or is destroied: but
being dead is raised up againe: this bo
dy therfore, or flesh is raised up again:
as though hee that maketh confession
of his beleefe should say, Our Lord di
ed even in the verie same condition of
nature that other mortall men doe die
in, but he carried not, nor yet stacke
fast among the dead. For the verie
same mortall flesh which hee had ta
ken unto him, and by dying had laid
aside, hee nowe taketh againe immor
talitie. As David had foretolde before
saying, Because thou shalt not leave
my soule in hel, nor suffer thy holy one
to see corruption.

For Christ is the first begotten of
them that rise againe, in whome as in
the head there ought to be declared in
what fort the resurrection of al Christ
his meber, shalbe in the day of judge
ment.

And we confesse that this resurrec
tion was made the third day, I meane
the third daie after his death. For
uppon the day of Preparation hee is
taken downe from the crosse, and ca
ried into a sepulchre, where his bodie
resteth the whole Sabboth day, and
about the beginning of the first day of
sabboths, which I say, is th first daye
of teh weeke, and among us at this
day is called Sunday, in the morning
he arose again from the dead. Wher
as therefore in the twelth chapter of
the Gospel after Saint Matthewe we
reade that the Lord saide: As Jonas
was three daies and three nights, in
the bellie of the Whale: So shall the
sonne of man bee in the heart of the
earth three dayes and three nights:
Yet notwithstanding in the fifteenth,
and twentie xhapiters expounding
himselfe, as having spoken that by
Synechdoche, hee sayth: I must goe to
Hierusalem, and suffer manie things
of the Scribes and Elders, and be kil
led, and raised up againe the thirde
day.

The sixt article of our faith is: He
ascended into Heaven, and sitteth at
the right hand of God the father al
mightie. That bodie which is of the
same substance with our bodies, ta
ken out of the Virgine Marie, and
taken verily of the substaunce of the
Virgin, which hoong upon the crosse,
and died, and was buried, and rose a
gaine, the verie same bodie, I say, as
scended into the heavens, and sitteth at
the right hand of God the father. For,
after that by the space of fortie dayes
our Lord had aboundantly inough in
structed his Disciples touching the
trueth of his resurrection & the king
dome of God, hee was taken up into
heaven.

By that ascension of his, hee decla
reth to the whole compasse of the
earth, that he is Lord of all things, &
that to him are subject all things that
are in heaven and in earth, that he is
our strength, the power of ye faithfull,
and he of whom they have to boast a
gainst the gates of Hel. For hee ascen
ding into heaven hath lead Captivitie
captive, and by spoiling his enemies
hath enriched his people, on whom hee
dayly heapeth his spirituall giftes.
For hee fitteth above, that by pow
ring his vertue from thence into us,
hee may quicken us with the spiri
tuall life, and decke us with sun
drie giftes and graces, and lastly, de
fend the Church agains all evils. For
God is a our saviour, king, and Bi
shop.

Whereupon when as once the
Capernaites were offended, because
the Lord had called him selfe the bread
of life, that came downe from Hea
ven, to give life unto the Worlde,
he saith: Doth this offend you? What
therefore if you shall see the sonne of
man ascende thither where hee was
before? As if hee shoulde say, then
verily yee will gather by my quicke
ning, resurrection, and glorious as
cension into the heavens, that I am
the bread of Life brought downe from
heaven, and now againe taken up in
to the heavens, there to remaine the
saviour, life, and Lord of heaven and
earth.

Moreover, S. Peter the Apostle in
the ACtes saith: Let all the house of Is
rael know for a suretie, that God hath
made the same Jesus whome yee have
crucified Lord and Christ.

Furthermore, he did not onely rise
againe from death, and come to his
Disciples, but also ascended into hea
ven as they beheld and looked on him,
to the ende, that we thereby might bee
assuredly certified of eternall salvati
on. for by ascending hee prepared a
place for us, he made readie the way,
that is, he opened the verie heavens to
the faithfull.

God hath placed in heaven the ve
rie humanitie that hee tooke of us:
which is in deede a lively and unre
proveable testimonie that all man
kinde shall at the last be translated in
to heaven also. For the members must
needes bee made conformable to the
head.

Christ our heade is risen againe
from the dead: therefore Wee his
members shall also rise againe. And
even as a cloude tooke away the Lord
from the sight of his Discilpes: So
shall we that beleeve be carried in the
cloudes to meete the Lorde, and shall
wholie in soule and bodie bee, and for
ever dwell in heaven with our head
and Lord Christ Jesus.

And this doth John evidently teach
him that readeth his fourteene chap
ter, where the Lord saith: I go to pre
pare a place for you, and will come
againe to you, and take you unto my
selfe, that wheresoever i am, ye may
also be.

Paul the Apostle also witnesseth,
and saith: Wee that live and shall be
remaining in the comming of the
Lorde, shall be carried in the clouds
together with them that are raised up
from the dead to meete the Lorde in
the aire. We confesse therefore in
this article, that Jesus Christ being
taken up into Heaven is Lorde of all
things, the king and BIshoppe, the
deliverer and saviour of all the faith
full in the whole worlde. Wee con
fesse, that in Christ, and for Christ
we believe the life everlasting, which
we shall have in this bodie at the end
of the worlde, and in soule so soone
as wee are once departed out of this
world.

But nowe by the way wee must
weigh the verie wordes of this arti
cle. Hee ascended, we saie. Who
ascended I pray you? Hee that was
borne of the virgine Marie, that was
crucified, dead and buried, that rose
againe from the dead: Hee (I say)
ascended verily both bodie and soule.
But whither ascended hee? Into
Heaven. Heaven in the Scriptures
is not taken alwayes in one significa
tion

First it is put for the firmament,
and that large compasse that is over
our heades, wherein the birds flie too
and fro, and in which the Starres are
placced that are called the furniture
and hoast of Heaven. For saith Da
vid: God is clothed with light as
with a garment, he spreadeth foorth
the Heaven as it were a Curtaine.
Hee saith also, I shall, see thy Hea
vens the worke of thy fingers, and
the Moone and STarres which thou
hast laide. And againe: Which co
vereth the Heaven with cloudes, and
prepareth raine for the earth. And
againe, The Heavens declare the glo
rie of God, and the firmament she
weth foorth the workes of his handes.
Then also, Heaven is taken for the
throne and habitation of God. And
lastly for the place, seate, and recepta
cle of them that are saved, where God
giveth himself to be seene and enjoyed
of them that be his.

For David witnessing againe,
saith, The Lorde hath prepared his
seate in Heaven: Whereuppon the
Lorde in the Gospel saith: Sweare not
by Heaven for it is Gods seate. And
the Apostle Paul saith; We knowe if
our earthly mansion of this tabernacle
be destroyed, that we have a dwelling
place for ever in Heaven, builded by
God, not made by handes.

And therefore in this signification
Heaven is called the kingdome of
God, the kingdome of the father, joy,
happinesse, and felicitie, eternall life,
peace and quietnesse.

And althought God in deede be not
shut up in any place. For hee saith:
Heaven is my seate, and the Earth the
footestoole of my feete: Yet because
the glorie of God doth most of all shine
in the Heavens, and because that in
heaven he giveth himselfe to be seene
and enjoyed of them that are his, ac
cording to that saying: We shall
see him even as he is. And againe,
No man shall see me, saith the Lord,
and live. Therefore God is saide to
dwell in Heaven.

kMoreover, Christ our Lorde tou
ching his divinitie, is not shnt uppe
in any place, but according to his hu
manitie once taken, which he drew up
into heaven, hee is in the verie locall
place of heaven, neither is he in the
meane time here in earth and everie
where bodilie, but being severed from
us in bodie, remaineth in heaven. For
hee ascendeth, which leaving that
which is belowe, doth goe to that a
bove.

Christ therefore leaving the earth,
hath placed a seate for his bodie above
all Heavens. Not that hee is carried
up beyond all Heavens, but because
ascending up above all the cirles into
the utmoseand highest Heaven, hee
is taken (I say) into the place appoin
ted for those that are saved. For Paul
the Apostle speaking plainely ynough
to be understoode, saith: Our conver
sation is in Heaven, from whence
we looke for kthe Savior to come,
&c.

In the same manner also Luke the
Evangelist saith: And blessing them,
he departed from them, and was caried
into Heaven.

But whie doe I make so much adoe
about expounding that which is most
evidently declared in the verie Creede
by that which followeth? For the next
is: He sitteth at the right hand of God
the father almightie.

For by this we understande what
kind of place Heaven is, and what our
Lord doth in heaven.

It is surely for our frailtie o
ver narrowly to seeke out or discusse
the secretes of heaven, and yet it is
not against Religion to enquire after
that that is taught us in the Scrip
tures, and so perfectly to remember
it as it is taught us. Our Lord is
simplie said to sit, and taht too, to
sit at the right hande of the father al
mightie.

Let us therefore see what the right
hand of the father is, and what it is
to sitte at the right hande of the Fa
ther.

The right hande of the father in
the Scripture hath two significati
ons. First the right hand of God is
the place appointed for them that are
saed, and the everlasting felicitie in
heaven.

This did S. Augustine set down to
be marked long before us, who in the
twentie and sixt chapter of his booke
De Agone Christiano writeth, That
the right hand of the father, is the
everlasting felicitie given to the
Saintes: even as also the left hande
is most rightlie called the continuall
miserie allotted to the ungodlie: not
so that by this meanes that I have
saide the right or lefte hande is to be
understoode in respect of GOD him
selfe, but in respect of his creatures
capacitie. And this did Saint Augu
stine speake according to the Scrip
tures. For David sayth: The path
of life shalt thou make knowne
to me the fulnesse of joyes is in thy
sight, and at thy right hand is gladnes,
for ever.

What else is this than if hee had
saide, Thou shalt bring me into life,
I say into the verie heavens, where
I shalbe filled with joyes, both by see
ing and beholding thee, and also by
enjoying thee. At thy right hand in e
ternall blessednsse are joyes everla
sting. In the gospell also wee reade,
that the Sheepe are placed by the
Judge at the right hand and the
Goats at the left. And when the right
hand is taken in this sense, then To
sitte dooth signifie to rest from all la
bours, and to live quietly and in hap
pie state. For that saying in the Pro
phet is verie well knowne: A man
shall sitte under his Vine. As if hee
should have said all thinges shall be at
peace, in safetie, and at quiet. So then
this that I have said, is meant by the
right hand of the father: and where
we confesse, that the sonne doth sitte
at the right hand of the father almigh
tie, we doe acknowledge, that our
Lorde being delivered from all trou
ble and mortall infirmities, doth now
in his humanitie, both rest and re
joice in the verie locall place of hea
ven, where we beleeve, that both our
soules and bodies shall be, and live for
ever.

For the Lord himselfe in the Gos
pell witnesseth, that in his fathers
house there are many mansions, which
he goeth to prepare, that they may
have a place, and although hee did de
part, yet that he woulde returne to
them againe, and take them unto him
selfe, that where he is, they also might
be in the same place with him.
Wherefore we belleve, that Christ is
at rest in Heaven where he hath pre
pared a place of rest for us also, to re
maine in joies everlasting. And for
because our bodies shall not be everie
where in felicitie, but in the onelie
appointed place, therefore said Saint
Augustine truly, that Christ our Lord
according to the measure of his verie
bodie is in some one place of heaven.
And Saint Cyprian saith: To sit at the
right hand of the father is the myste
rie of his fleshe taken uppe into Hea
ven.

Secondarilie the right hand of God
is put for the vertue, kingdome, pro
tection, deliveraunce and power of
God. For David saith: The Lordes
right hand is hight, the Lordes right
hand doth mightie thinges. And Mo
ses saide, Thy right hand (O Lorde)
is mgnified in power, they right hand
(O Lord) hath broken the enemie And
when the right hand is put in this
sense, then To sit doth signifie to raign,
to deliver, to use power, and do the of
fice of a Prince.

For, saith David: The Lorde saide
into my Lorde, sit thou at my right
hand, till I make thine enemies thy
footestoole. And the Prophet Za
charie saith. Beholde the man, that
is called the braunch, he shall budde
out of his place, and builde the Temple
of the Lorde, and sitte and rule upon
his throne, and be a Priest uppon his
seate. In this sense the right hand of
God is infinite and contained in no
measure of place: whereas wee con
fesse, that our Lorde doeth sitte at the
right hand of the father, wee doe pro
fesse, that the sonne is exalted above
all thinges, having all things subject
under him selfe, as Paule in his
first chapter to the Ephesians saith:
and finally, that the sonne being so
exalted can doe all things, doth raign
in the universall Church doth deli
ver them that are his, doth make
intercession to the father in Heaven,
and in the power of his Godhead is
present in all places. For therefore did
the Creede adde Almightinesse to this
sitting of his, where it is saide, He
sitteth at the right hande of the father
almightie. And in Saint Matthew the
Lorde sayth, To me is given all might
in heaven, and in earth, goe therefore
and bring al nations unto me.

So then I suppose that briefly thus
I have well declared what manner of
place heaven is, to wit, a place of qui
etnesse, joy, and everlasting felicitie,
wherein the sonne of God doth sit, doth
dwell, and is in his humanitie, as we
also, that are the members of Christ,
shalbe in the verie same place without
all dolour and griefe in joye for ever
more. And although our Lorde be de
livered from all grievous businesse,
yet we meane not that he sitteth idel
ly leaning on his elbowes. For he is a
king, a Priest, and verie God in the
verie temple of God: he cannot choose
therefore of his naturall propertie and
office but work salvation in the elect,
and do all things, that lie God a king,
and Priest in hande to doe. So then
nowe we all knowe what our Lorde
doth as he sitteth in heaven. Neither
is it any trouble to him at al to do and
worke that which he doth, for he wor
keth not of compulsion, but naturally
and of his owne accorde.

Thus and no otherwise did the an
cient interpreters of the holie Scrip
tures handle this article of our belief.
Some of whose testimonies I will
here alledge. Saint Hierome in his
exposition of Paules first Chapter to
the Ephesians, saith: he hath decla
red the power of God by the simili
tude of a man: not because a seate is
placed and God the father sitteth ther
on, having his sonne sitting there with
him: but because we cannot other
wise conceive howe the sonne dooth
judge and reigne, but by such wordes
applyed to our capacitie. As therefore
to be next to God, or to depart farre
from him is not to be understood ac
cording to the distance of places, but
after mens merites, because the saints
are heard by him, but the sinnes (of
whome the Prophete saieth, Beholde
they that gette themselves from thee
shall perish) are removed farre enough
for comming neare him at all. Even so
likewise to bee eyther at the right of
left hande of God is to bee taken so,
that the saints are at his right hand and
sinners at his left. As our saviour
him selfe also in the Gospell affirming
the same doeth say, that at the right
hand are the sheepe, and the goates
at the left. Moreover this verie word
(to Sit) doeth argue the power of a
kingdome, by which God is benefici
all to them on whom he doeth vouch
safe to sit, in so much as verilie he doth
rule them, and hath them alwayes in
his guiding, & doth turne to his owne
becke or government, the necks of the
that before ran out of the way at ran
don, and at libertie.

Saint Augustine in his booke De
Fide & Symbolo sayth, We beleeve that
sitteth at the right hande of God
the Father. Yet not so therefore as
though we shoulde thinke that God
the Father is comprehended within
the limittes of a mans bodie: so that
they that thinke of him shoulde ima
gine that hee hath both a right and a
left side: And whereas it is sayde that
the Father sitteth, we must not sup
pose that he doeth sitte with bended
hammes, least peradventure wee fall
into the same sacriledge for which the
Apostle accurseth them that have
chaunged the glorie of the Incorrup
tible God, into the similitude of a cor
ruptible man. For a detestable thing
it is to place God in such a likenesse in
a Christian Church: and much more
wicked is it to place it in the heart,
where the temple of God is verily and
in deede, if it be cleansed from earth
ly desires and errour. We must there
fore understand that at the right hand
is as much to say as in greatest happi
nesse, where righteousnesse and peace
gladnes is: even as also the Goats
are placed at the left hand, that is in
miserie for their iniquities to their
paine and torment. Whereas God
therefore is said to sit thereby is not
meant the placing of his lims, but his
judicial power, which his majesty ne
ver wanteth in bestowing worthie re
wardes on those that are worthy of
them. And so foorth.

The blessed Bishop Fulgentius in
his second booke to king Trasimun
dus, sayth: The Lorde, to shewe that
his humanitie is locall, sayth to his
Disciples, I ascended to my father and
to your father, my God and your God.
And by and by after declaring the in
comprehensibilitie of his Godhead, he
sayeth to his Disciples: Behold I am
with you alwayes even unto the end of
the world.

The blessed Martyr and Bishoppe
of Trent Vigilius in his first booke a
gainst heresies, sayth: This was to go
to the Father, and to depart from us,
to take away out of this world the na
ture which he tooke of us Thou
seest therefore that it was proper to
the same nature to be taken away, and
to depart from us, according to the
wordes of the Angels which sayd,
This Jesus who is taken up from you,
shall come againe even as yee see him
goe into heaven. For see the myracle,
See the mysterie of both his proper
ties: The Sonne of God in his huma
nitie is departed from us according to
his divinitie he sayth to us, Behold I
am with you alwaies even unto the end
of the world. If he be with us howe
sayth he? The time shal come when ye
shall desire to see one of the dayes of
the sonne of man and ye shal not see it,
Both he is with us, and not with us. Be
cause them, whom he hath left and de
parted from in his Godhead, he hath not
left norforsaken in his manhood. This
sayth he.

The seventh Article of our fayth is
this. From thence he shall come to
judge the quicke and the dead. In
the former ARticles there is set foorth
and confessed the divine goodnesse,
bountifulnesse and grace in Christ:
nowe also shall be declared the divine
justice, severitie and vengeaunce that
is in him. for there are two comings
of our Lorde Jesus Christ. First he
came basely in the fleshe to bee the re
deemer and saviour of the worlde. At
the second time he shall come glorious
ly to judgement to be a judge and re
venger that will not be inttreated a
gainst all unrepentaunt sinners and
wicked doers. And he shall come out of
heaven from the right hand of the FA
ther in his visible and verie humane
bodie, to be seene of all flesh, with the
incomprehensible power of his God
head, and being attended on by all the
Angels. For the Lord himselfe in the
Gospell sayth: They shall see the sonne
of man coming in the cloudes of hea
ven with great power and glory, & he
shal send his angels with ye great sound
of a trump. &c But now to judge is to
sit in the tribunal seate, to heare and dis
cusse matters, to take up strifes to de
termine and give sentence, and lastly
to defend & deliver, and againe to cha
stise and punish, & by ye meanes to keep
under & suppresse injurie and malice.
We beleeve therefore that our Lorde
Jesus Christ in that day shall deliver
all the godly and destroy al ye wicked:
according to the wordes of the Apostle
who sayth: Our Lord shall be revealed
fro heaven with the Angels of hs peo
wer, with a burning flame, and shall
lay vengeance on them that have not
knowne God: And againe, the same
just judge shall give a crowne of righ
teousnesse to all them that love his fco
ming. The manner of this judgement
the writings of the Evangelistes & A
postles doe tell us, shall be in this fort.
When once the wickednesse of this
world shall come to the full, & that An
tichrist shall have deceived the world,
so that there is but little faith remai
ning, & that the wicked shall say peace
and quitnesse, then shall a sodaine de
structio come. For our Lord the judge
shall sende his Archangel, to blowe the
trump & to gather together from the
foure winds al flesh to judgemet: by &
by after shall the judge him selfe our
Lord Jesus Christ follow with all the
hoast of heaven: & he shall descend out
of heaven into the cloudes: and fitting
aloft in the cloudes as in a judgement
seate, shalbe easilie seene of al flesh For
they that shall bee then living at the
day of judgement shall in a very prick
of time by changed, & stande before the
indge: and all the deade shall in a mo
ment rise up againe. Then shall the
judge divide the sheepe from the goats:
& according to justice shal give judge
met with the sheep &against the goats
saying. Come ye blessed &c. And, Goe
ye cursed. &c. Presently after shall fol
lowe execution. For the sheepe shall by
and by be caught up into the clouds to
meete ye Lord in the ayre, & shal ascend
with him joyfully into heaven to the
right hand of God the father, there to
live for ever in glorie & gladnesse. The
bottome of the earth shall gape for the
wicked, & shall sucke them all by hor
ribly, & send them downe to hell, there
to be tormented for ever with Satan
and his angels. All this shall be done
not by any long, troublesom or chage
able processe, as is used in our Courts
of lawe, but even in the twinckling of
an eye. For then shall all mens hearts
be laide open & everie mans own con
science shall accurse himselfe. This is
more at lage set out in Mat. 24. &25.
Wis. 3. & 5.1. Cor. 15.2. Cor.5.1. The
4.5. Rom. 2.2. Yet. 3.&c. Nower we doe
simply confesse that the quicke and the
dead shalbe judged. This doe some ex
pound of the godly & ungodly. But the
/>Symbole or Creede, was ordeyned for
the most simple of understanding. And
simple thinges are fittest for to teach
simple men. Therefore we say simply ye
the dead are all they, that from the be
ginning of the worlde even until the
last day are departed out of this mor
tall life. And the living are they which
at that day shalbe alive in this world.
For the Apostle saith: Behold I tell you
a mysterie, we shall not all sleepe, but
wee shall all be channged by the last
trump in a moment of time and in the
twinckling of an eye. For the trumpe
shal sounde, and the dead shall rise a
shal sounde, and the dead shall rise a
gaine incorruptible, and wee shall bee
chaunged.

And again in another place the same
Apostle sayth: This I say unto you in
the worde of the Lord, that we, which
shal live and be remaining at the com
ming of the Lorde, shall not prevent
them which are a sleepe. Because the
Lorde himselfe shall come downe out
of heaven with a great noyse, and the
voice of an Archangell and the trump
of God, and first shall the deade in
Christ rise, up againe, then shall we
which shall be alive and be remaining,
be caught up together with them in
the cloudes into the ayre to meete the
Lorde: and so shall we be with the
Lord for evermore.

Wee confesse therefore in this se
veth Article that wee beleeve there
shall bee an ende of all thinges in
this world, and that the felicitie of the
wicked shall not endure for ever. For
we beleve that God is a just God who
hath given all judgement unto his
Son, to repay to everie one in that day
according to his works, paines to the
wicked that never shall be ended, and
to the godly joyes everlasting. And so
in this Article wee professe that wee
looke for a deliverance, a ceasing from
troubbles, and the reward of life ever
lasting. For nowe shoulde hee destroy
them that beleeve in him, his people,
and his servauntes, who in the most
true Gospell sayeth: Verily I say unto
you that ye, which have followed me
in the regeneration, when the Sonne
of man shall sit on the seate of his ma
jestie, yee also shall sit upon twleve
seates judging the twelve tribes of Is
raell. There are most certaine re
wardes and penalties appointed for
the godly and ungodly in the worde of
trueth. He can not lie that saide to E
say, Say to the righteous that it shall
goe well with him, for he shall injoy
the fruite of his studie. But woe be to
the wicked, it shall be evill with him,
for he shall be rewarded according to
the workes of his owne handes. And
thus much touching the seconde part
of the Creede. Nowe are wee come to
the thirde part.

The eight Article of our beleife is
this, I beleeve in the holy Ghost. This
thirde part of the Creede contayneth
the propertie of the third person in the
reverend Trinitie. And we doe right
ly beleeve in the holy Ghost, as wel as
in the father and the son. For the ho
ly Ghost is one God with the Father
and the Sonne: and rightly is faith in
the holy Ghost joyned to faith in the
Father and the Sonne. For by him
the fruite of Gods salvation fulfilles
in the sonne is sealed to us, and our
sanctification and cleansing is besto
wed on us, and derived from him to
us by the holy Ghost. For the Apo
stle sayth: God which annointed us, is
he also which hath sealed us, and hath
given the earnest of the spirite in our
hearts. And againe, Ye were in deede
defiled with naughtinesse, but nowe
yee are cleansed and sanctified, and
lastlie justified through the name of
the Lorde Jesus, and by the spirite of
our God. The Father in deede doeth
sanctifie too, but by the bloud of Jesus
Christ, and powreth the same sanctifi
cation out of him into us by the holy
Ghost: so that it is as it were the pro
pertie of the holie Ghost to sanctifie
whereupon hee is called Holy or the
sanctifier. Therefore so often as wee
heare the holie Ghost named, we must
by and by thinke of the power in wor
king, which the Scripture attributeth
to him, and we must looke after the be
nefites that from him doe flowe to us.
For the power, operation, or action of
the spirite is that, what so ever the
grace of God doth work in us through
the Sonne: so that of necessitie wee
must beleeve in the holie Ghost. And
in this eight Article we doe professe,
that we doe verily beleeve that all the
faithfull are cleansed, washed regene
rated, sanctified, inlightned, and inri
ched of God with divers gifts of grace
for Christ his sake, but yet through ye
holy Ghost. For without him there is
no true sanctification: wherefore we
ought not to attribute these giftes of
grace to any other meanes: this glory
belongeth to the holie Ghost onely Of
whome I will more largely and fully
discourse in my other Sermons.

The houre is spent which warneth
me to wrappe up briefly and make an
end, therefore I exhort you all to have
your faith religiously bent uppon the
Lord Jesus: for him hath the heaven
ly father sent to us, in him that hee
wholely expressed and shewed himselfe
to us, and him doeth the holie Ghost
print in our heartes and keepe in our
mindes. And in Christ is all mans sal
vation and everie part thereof contai
ned: Wherefore we must beware that
we derive it not from anie thing else.
It pleased the father (saith the Apostle)
that all fulnesse shoulde dwell in the
Sonne, and in him to recapitulate and
as it were to bring into a summe all
points of salvation, that in him all the
faithfull may be fulfilled. For it sal
vation be sought, then even by his ve
ry name are we taught that salvation
is in his power. For hee is called Je
sus, that is a saviour. If we desire the
holy spirite of God & his sundry gifts,
we shall finde them also in the annoin
ting of Christ. For he is called Christ,
the annoynted I saye, the holie of
holies, and the sanctifier, or else the an
noynter of us with his spirite. If any
man have need of strength and might,
of power and deliveraunce, well hee
hath to looke for it in Christ his domi
nion. For Christ is Lorde of all. In
the same Christ we finde redemption.
For he hath redeemed us that were
solde under Sathans yoake. In his
conception we have puritie, in his na
tivitie we have sufferance. For he be
came like to us, that hee might suffer
griefe as well as wee. For in his pas
sion we have forgivenesse of sinnes, in
his condemnation wee have absoluti
on, satisfactio in his offering or clean
sing sacrifice, cleansing in his bloud,
and an universal reconciliation in his
descending into hell. In his buriall
we have the mortification of our flesh,
the newnesse of life, yea rather the im
mortalitie of the soule, and resurrectio
on of our bodies in his glorious resur
rection. He have also the inheritance
of the heavenly kingdome, with the
allured sealing thereof in his ascension
and sitting at the right hand of the fa
ther. And there is hee our mediatour,
priest and king, our safegarde and our
heade, our defender and most sure
rest.

From thence he poureth into us his
holy spirite, the fulnesse of all good
thinges: and doeth communicate him
selfe wholy to us, joyning us unto him
selfe with an indissoluble knot. From
thence we doe with confidence and joy
looke for him to be our judge, to bee I
say our patron and deliverer, which
shall condemne and sende downe hed
long into hell all our enemies with sa
than: but shall take us and al the faith,
full of everie age up into heaven with
himselfe, there to sing a new song, and
to rejoyce in him forever and ever.
To him be glorie for ever. Amen.
Of the latter Articles of Christian faith contained
in the Apostles Creede.
